item.title: Control developer Remedy names former EA exec as new CEO
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 9, 2026

1 Min Read

Image via Remedy Entertainment

Former EA executive Jean-Charles Gaudechon has been named CEO of Remedy Entertainment. 

The Alan Wake and Control developer shared the news in a brief note to investors and explained Gaudechon will step into the role on March 1, 2026. Interim CEO and co-founder Markus Mäki will continue overseeing operations until Gaudechon begins his tenure. 

Remedy has been searching for a new permanent CEO since Tero Virtala departed the studio after almost a decade in October 2025. Virtala's exit came with FBC: Firebreak, the Finnish studio's first self-published title, struggling to make a significant impact after four months on shelves. 

Gaudechon spent over 15 years at EA across two stints at the U.S. publisher, where he assumed profit and loss responsibility for the group's operations in Asia and prior to that served as studio head and executive producer at EA's free-to-play studio in Stockholm. During his time at EA, Gaudechon helped steer live-service operations for titles such as FIFA Mobile and Battlefield Heroes.

Related:The biggest Roblox creators earned an average of $1.3 million in 2025

The veteran exec also previously served as general manager and executive producer at CCP Games' studio in Shanghai, China. 

Discussing his new role, Gaudechon said he intends to help Remedy scale in a way that "builds lasting value."

"Remedy has the voice and the ambition to be a pillar of the industry's future. We will stay close to players, earn their time and trust, and strengthen our independence in how we build and publish our games, while continuing to work closely with the partners who have supported us along the way," he added. 

"I will be moving to Finland with my family and I’m incredibly excited about getting to work directly with the team at the studio."

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.

item.title: Discord will soon require age verification for full access
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 9, 2026

2 Min Read

Game-focused chat and community platform, Discord, will soon require users to submit face scans or identity documents as part of a new "teen-by-default" age verification mandate. 

The company said the move will enhance "age-appropriate protections while maintaining privacy, community, and meaningful connection on the platform." 

The measure will result in all users being handed a teen-appropriate experience by default that will restrict access to age-gated spaces, implement content filtering, and prohibit some forms of communication. 

Following the beginning of a phased global rollout in March, Discord users will need to complete an age verification process in order to change those settings. The company has already implemented age-verification in the UK and Australia. 

The changes will arrive around a year after Discord and Roblox were both accused of 'facilitating the sexual exploitation' of a minor in a lawsuit filed in California. 

Related:Scopely confirms it used generative AI to advertise Star Trek Fleet Command

"Age assurance is the foundation of this new experience and is designed to respect Discord users’ privacy and choice. Discord users can choose to use facial age estimation or submit a form of identification to its vendor partners, with more options coming in the future," reads a Discord blog post. 

"Additionally, Discord will implement its age inference model, a new system that runs in the background to help determine whether an account belongs to an adult, without always requiring users to verify their age. Some users may be asked to use multiple methods if more information is needed to assign an age group."

Discord said its approach to age-assurance will ensure video selfies used for facial age estimation never leave a user's device, and that identity documents submitted to its vendor partners are swiftly deleted. 

It noted that most users will only be asked to complete the process once, but explained some might be asked for multiple methods of verification "when more information is needed to assign an age group."

The news comes with Discord reportedly preparing to go public—and just months after the company confirmed a data breach impacting one of its third-party customer service providers may have exposed the government-ID photographs of around 70,000 users.

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.
